When we talk about expanding access to mental health care, let's not forget about the doctors and nurses who sacrifice so much to keep us healthy.

Because we're all in this together. #MentalHealthMonday

One way we can address burnout is by addressing the staffing shortage.

Recently, I was proud to cosponsor a bill that would establish federal nurse-to-patient staffing ratios‚Äîreducing the pressure on our nurses and improving patient health outcomes at the same time.

Burnout has long been a problem in the health care industry.

Even before the pandemic, 70% of primary care providers reported feelings of burnout.

And when providers are pushed to their limits, patients suffer, too.

Health care providers work long hours and deal with life or death situations on a daily basis.

As a result, many doctors and nurses suffer from increased stress, exhaustion, and other mental health problems related to burnout.

So let's talk about it. üßµ

üìà In 2013, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta lifted the ban on women serving in direct ground combat roles. Since 2015, more than 100 women have graduated from Army Ranger School, and women make up 19% of enlisted forces and 20% of the officer corps! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FydePXgWwAEDOlM.png

üöÅ In 1993, after President Clinton rescinded the ‚ÄúRisk Rule,‚Äù women were finally able to serve in all positions in the military except direct ground combat. This meant that women could finally fly in combat‚Ä¶ and was the year I went to flight school! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fydd-DCXgA0BQ1k.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FydeBH_XwAAKvMA.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FydeD-LWAAEsNsy.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FydeI_bWYAE_jbB.png

üìö In 1976, President Ford signed Public Law 94-106, allowing for women to attend military academies. Since the first graduating class in 1980, more than 20,000 women have graduated from one of our nation‚Äôs military academies! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FyddtAIWIAISHHl.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FyddwXiWIAcsNo7.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fydd2yCX0AEEm4a.png

ü´° On June 12th, 1948, President Truman signed the Women‚Äôs Armed Services Integration Act, finally allowing women to officially serve in the U.S. military. However this capped the number of women able to serve at 2% and prevented them from serving in combat or leadership roles. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fyddn4cXsAEl7ig.png

üßµ Before the late 1940‚Äôs, women were unable to officially serve in the military. But that didn‚Äôt stop us‚Ä¶ as far back as the Revolutionary War - and in every conflict since - women served as nurses, cooks & secretaries providing essential services to support the war effort. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FyddjhKXwAIB2ep.png

@momosmomma He passed 20 years ago today.
Gregory Peck was a great actor, but he was also a very kind man and an all around great human being.

Two years later, I ran into him at the Democratic National Convention in LA when he attended the Virginia Delegation party.  I said, ‚ÄúMr. Peck, you probably don‚Äôt remember me but‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the lawyer from Petersburg!‚Äù

Much to his agent‚Äôs chagrin, he talked to me for about 10 minutes. He said ‚ÄúI get thousands of letters every year, and something about your letter touched me and I had to meet you!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, so can I write to you again?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúPlease do!‚Äù So I did. He wrote back.

During the Q&A portion of the show he invited A LOT of people backstage. So, his agent instructed ‚ÄúSay hello, take your picture and go!‚Äù

When it was my turn and I introduced myself he said ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the lawyer from Petersburg! Come sit with me for a minute.‚Äù

A few weeks later, I got a package in the mail with an autographed picture and a note from his personal assistant inviting me and Dad to attend his show at the Barter Theater in Abingdon.  When I called to confirm, she said I was invited to meet him backstage!

He was scheduled for Wilmington, DE and Abingdon, VA, so I wrote a letter to see if he might be coming to Richmond or DC. 

I didn‚Äôt hear anything, so Dad and I made the drive to Wilmington for a lovely evening. Peck was one of Dad‚Äôs favorites, too!
